questions.prompt: Which of the following collections forms a topology on X = {a, b, c}?
questions.explanation: A topology must contain ∅ and X, and be closed under arbitrary unions and finite intersections. {∅, {a}, {a, b}, X} satisfies all requirements: {a} ∪ {a, b} = {a, b} ✓, {a} ∩ {a, b} = {a} ✓. The other options fail: {∅, {a}, {b}, X} fails because {a} ∪ {b} = {a,b} is not in the collection; {∅, {a}, {b}, {a, b}} is missing X; {∅, X} is the indiscrete topology but not the question's answer.

questions.prompt: In any topological space, the empty set ∅ is always an open set.
questions.explanation: By definition, a topology must contain both ∅ and the whole space X. Therefore, ∅ is always open in any topology.

questions.prompt: Which statement is NOT an equivalent definition of a closed set F?
options: F contains all its limit points
F is the complement of an open set
F contains at least one limit point
questions.explanation: The first three options are all equivalent definitions of a closed set. However, 'F contains at least one limit point' is not a valid definition - a closed set must contain ALL its limit points, not just one. Additionally, finite sets in discrete spaces are closed but may have no limit points.

questions.prompt: The interior of a set A is the largest open set contained in A.
questions.explanation: By definition, int(A) is the union of all open sets contained in A, making it the largest open set within A.

questions.prompt: For the set A = [0, 1) in ℝ with standard topology, what is cl(A)?
questions.explanation: The closure of [0, 1) includes all its limit points. Both 0 and 1 are limit points (every neighborhood of 1 intersects [0, 1)), so cl(A) = [0, 1].

title: Topological Spaces - Open and Closed Sets

questions.prompt: The union of infinitely many closed sets is always closed.
questions.explanation: False. Counterexample: In ℝ, each [1/n, 1] is closed, but ⋃[1/n, 1] = (0, 1] which is not closed. Only finite unions of closed sets are guaranteed to be closed.

questions.prompt: In the discrete topology on any set X, which sets are open?
questions.explanation: In the discrete topology, every subset of X is open (and also closed). This is the finest topology possible on X.

questions.prompt: What is the interior of ℚ (rationals) in ℝ with standard topology?
questions.explanation: int(ℚ) = ∅ because ℚ contains no open intervals. Every open interval contains both rationals and irrationals, so no point of ℚ is an interior point.

questions.prompt: A set can be both open and closed (clopen) in a topological space.
questions.explanation: True. At minimum, ∅ and X are always both open and closed. In some topologies (like discrete), many more sets are clopen.

questions.prompt: For A = {1/n : n ∈ ℕ} in ℝ, what is cl(A)?
questions.explanation: The sequence 1/n → 0 as n → ∞, so 0 is a limit point of A. No other points are limit points, so cl(A) = A ∪ {0}.

title: Topological Spaces - Limit Points and Boundary

questions.prompt: A point x is a limit point of A if:
options: Every neighborhood of x contains a point of A different from x
Every neighborhood of x intersects A
questions.explanation: By definition, x is a limit point of A if every neighborhood of x contains at least one point of A distinct from x. This allows x to be in or out of A.

questions.prompt: Every point of a set A is necessarily a limit point of A.
questions.explanation: False. In the discrete topology, isolated points exist. For example, in ℝ with discrete topology, no point is a limit point of any set.

questions.prompt: What is the boundary ∂A of the set A = (0, 1] in ℝ?
questions.explanation: The boundary is ∂A = cl(A) \ int(A). We have cl(A) = [0, 1] and int(A) = (0, 1), so ∂A = {0, 1}.

questions.prompt: If A is open, then ∂A ∩ A = ∅.
questions.explanation: True. If A is open, then A = int(A). The boundary is ∂A = cl(A) \ int(A) = cl(A) \ A, which is disjoint from A.

questions.prompt: In the indiscrete topology on X = {a, b, c}, how many limit points does {a} have?
questions.explanation: In the indiscrete topology, the only open sets are ∅ and X. Every neighborhood of any point is X, which always intersects {a}. Therefore, every point a, b, c is a limit point of {a}.
